Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2017 Midwest Conference on Representation Theory will be held October 20- 22, 2017, on the campus of Purdue University in West Lafayette, IN. The conference will gather established experts, recent Ph.D.s, and graduate students for the purpose of discussing and disseminating new results in the broad area of Representation Theory, a fundamental mathematical subject with applications to many other areas within mathematics.

Nine speakers have been invited to this year's conference, including several early-career researchers. The conference will also feature talks by established researchers whose specialties include automorphic forms, and representation theory. The conference website is https://www.math.purdue.edu/calendar/conferences/midreptheory17/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
he 2017 Midwest Representation Theory Conference was held at Purdue University, October 20-22, 2017. The conference was organized by S. DeBacker (Michigan), D. Goldberg (Purdue), D. Jiang (Minnesota), M. Krishnamurthy (Iowa), L. Spice (TCU), and S. Takeda (Missouri). There were 9 speakers over the course of three days: A. Altug (Boston U), C. Chan (U. Michigan),  J. Cogdell (Ohio State U.), E. Eischen (U. Oregon), R. Howe (Texas A&M), B.C Ng? (U. Chicago), A. Parab (Purdue), A. Raghuram (IISER Pune), and C. Wan (IAS). These lectures addressed a broad range of topics in representation theory and included applications to other areas of research, including number theory, algebraic geometry, and harmonic analysis. In keeping with the tradition of the Midwest Conference, many of these speakers are early career researchers, including two graduate students close to finishing their doctorates (Chan, Parab), one with a  postdoctoral appointments (Wan), and twowas a tenure track assistant professors (Altug, Eischen).

 

The  Conference was attended by 65 registered  participants, of which 21 were supported through this award including many of the speakers. There were several, local, unsupported participants (including one speaker and one organizer), and several unregistered local participants. Of the 65 registered participants, 21 were graduate students, 9 were postdoctoral faculty, 9 were untenured tenure track faculty, and  and 26 were tenured faculty.Ten of the registered particpants were female. Of the 21 supportd participants, 9 were graduate students, 4 were  postdoctoral faculty, 3 were non-tenured tenure track faculty, and 5 were tenured faculty. There were five supported female participants (all juniior participants). Four of the 21 supported participants were from foreign institutions (Canada, China France, and India). Purdue University generously supplemented the funds provided by this award. The organizers are confident in attesting this conference was of high academic standards and served to further the depth and scope of research in the broad field of representation theory. All $20,000 of the award were spent on participant travel and local expenses.
